item.title: The Missing Semester of your CS Education [MIT]
02. Shell Tools
item.description: Topic 2: Shell Tools. https://missing.csail.mit.edu/2020/shell-tools/ . Unlike other scripting programming languages, shell scripting is optimized for shell related tasks, e.g. reading from STDIN and saving results into files are primitives. At the cost of being painful on the eyes. Python scripts are way more readable (and cross-platform) than shell scripts. Pesky Whitespace 1 2 3 foo = bar # Doesn't work because it's interpreted as calling the foo program with the args '=' and 'bar' foo=bar # Now that works!

item.title: 06. Version Control (Git)
item.description: Version Control Systems track changes to a folder and its contents in a series of snapshots. Each snapshot encapsulates the entire state of files/folders within a top-level directory. Git’s interface is a leaky abstraction. While the interface is at times ugly, its underlying design and ideas are beautiful. A bottom-up explanation of Git therefore makes more sense. Snapshots A blob corresponds to a file, and it’s just a bunch of bytes.

item.title: Miscellaneous Topics
item.description: Personalizing Your Shell Put all of your scripts in the ~/bin/ directory, and add ~/bin/ to your path. Beware of conflicting with system commands. One alternative is to prefix your commands with a comma. [] References Start all of your commands with a comma. Brandon Rhodes. https://rhodesmill.org/brandon/2009/commands-with-comma/ . https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=22778988 . Aug 18, 2009.
